bibl.title: Franscois Lafontaisis v. United States
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

msIdentifier.repository: Washington State Archives, Eastern Regional Branch
msIdentifier.collection: Walla Walla County Government; Clerk, Territorial Court Civil/Criminal Case Files, 1860-1889

body.p: For District Court First Judicial District
To the Hon Samuel Wingard judge of the first judcial district Washington Territory holding times at Walla Walla County

The petition of Francois LafonTaisis respectfully shows to your honor that he is now a prisoner confined in the custody of George F Thomas sheriff of the county of Walla Walla Washington territory in the county jail of said county for a supposed criminal offense to with "selling liquor to Indians" as will more freely appear by reference to the indictment upon which your petitioner was tried now in file in this court
Your petitioner also shows that such confinement is by virtue of the sentence of this court a copy of which is here to annexed and made a part of this petition

And your petitioner answers that to the best of his knowledge and belief that at the time of his said trial and
and confinement he had not been guilty of the violations of any of the laws of the United States and especially not guilty of the violations of the statute prohibiting the sale of alcohol to Indians, and that the indictment apon which your petitioner was tried and convicted and is now undergoing sentence charged no offense known to the law

And your petitioner further states that he is advised by caunsel Missers Caton and Nash residing at Walla Walla WT and so believes that his said imprisonment is illegal and that said illegality consists in this towith that your petitioner was convicted of an offense unknown to the law of the United States. And that the law under which the court precluded to act and upon which your petitioner was tried and convicted and is now undergoing sentence was at the time of such trial and conviction repealed and abrogated your petitioner prays a writ of habeus corpus to the end so that he may be discharged from custody
Franscois Lafontaisis by Caton and Nash his attorneys
